prompt: A 55-year-old female presents with progressive pain in both hands, particularly in the fingers. She reports morning stiffness lasting about 30 minutes, difficulty gripping objects, and visible swelling in the finger joints. The pain is worse after periods of inactivity. What is the likely diagnosis and recommended workup?

reasoning.age_and_gender: RA is more common in women, often presenting between ages 30-60
symptom_pattern: Progressive pain - RA is chronic, progressive inflammatory condition
Bilateral hand involvement - RA typically affects joints symmetrically
Finger involvement (MCP and PIP joints) - classic for RA
Morning stiffness >30 minutes - hallmark of inflammatory arthritis
Difficulty gripping - related to pain and swelling
Pain worse after inactivity - typical of inflammatory arthritis

differential_diagnoses.notes: Usually affects DIP joints, CMC joint of thumb. Morning stiffness typically <30 minutes. Bony swelling rather than soft tissue.
Can affect hands, often asymmetrically. May involve DIP joints. Associated with psoriasis.
Can cause arthritis, often non-erosive. Usually accompanied by other systemic symptoms.
Typically acute, monoarticular attacks. Polyarticular forms exist.
Widespread pain without significant joint swelling or prolonged morning stiffness.

history_and_physical: Detailed history - onset, duration, progression, specific joints, stiffness duration
Physical exam - assess all joints for swelling, tenderness, warmth, redness, ROM, deformity
Look for extra-articular manifestations (rheumatoid nodules, vasculitis, lung findings)
laboratory_tests: Rheumatoid Factor (RF) - positive in ~70-80% of RA patients
ESR and CRP - markers of inflammation
imaging_studies: Hand and Wrist X-rays (AP and Lateral) - assess erosions, joint space narrowing, periarticular osteopenia
Ultrasound or MRI - more sensitive for early synovitis and erosions

key_points: Early diagnosis and treatment crucial to prevent joint damage
response.disclaimer: This information is for general guidance only and does not substitute for professional medical advice.
